WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Your ear listens to your heart and feels shame. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Feel the shame. Feel the shame in both your ear and your heart. Imagine the things you’ve done to make you feel so much shame.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You must cleanse your spirit of this shame. You decide to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “HAHAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: You’re super embarrassed for bringing so much shame on yourself again. But then you think of another joke. “Hahaha!” Better luck with the next Haj, I guess.

humanum_full_description_en:
From the " heart " and " ear " sound, the original meaning is shame. "Said Wen": "Humiliation. From the heart, to the ears." Han Sima Qian (Report to Ren Shaoqing): "Every time I read the shame, the sweat is not unreasonable."

" Shame " can mean shame. "The Twelve Years of Gu Liang Chuan-Huan Gong": "If you don't talk about fighting with Zheng, it's shameful and discordant."

" Shame " also means insult and humiliation. "Zuo Zhuan‧ The Five Years of Zhao Gong": "You can't be unprepared to shame a man. What is the shame of the country? It is a sacramental service, and no shame is required."
humanum_short_description_en: From the " heart " and " ear " sound, the original meaning is shame.
humanum_full_description:
從「心」，「耳」聲，本義為恥辱。《說文》：「辱也。从心，耳聲。」 漢司馬遷〈報任少卿書〉：「每念斯恥，汗未嘗不發背沾衣也。」

　　「恥」可表示羞愧。《穀梁傳‧桓公十二年》：「不言與鄭戰，恥不和也。」

　　「恥」也表示侮辱、羞辱。《左傳‧昭公五年》：「恥匹夫不可以無備，況恥國乎？是以聖王務行禮，不求恥人。」
